newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Two islands activists rescued from sea - radio.
newsitem.headline: Two islands activists rescued from sea - radio.

text.p: Two activists demonstrating against Japan's claim to a group of East China Sea islands fell overboard their protest vessel on Monday and were rescued by colleagues, Hong Kong radio reported.

The accident happened as Taiwan and Hong Kong activists pierced a Japanese maritime cordon and planted the flags of China and Taiwan on one of the islands in a challenge to Japan's claim to sovereignty.
The action by 50 boats from Taiwan carrying about 300 activists from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau, was the latest in two months of escalating anti-Japanese protests.
Hong Kong radio said two activists went overboard as the protest flotilla became involved in a face-off with a Japanese force of about 30 vessels. The two were not named.
"It appears they were rescued after a short time without serious injuries," the radio's correspondent on board one of the vessels reported.

In an earlier protest on September 26, a Hong Kong protest leader drowned after jumping off a ship near the islands northeast of Taiwan. Thousands of Hong Kong people turned out to mourn David Chan at his funeral on Sunday.
Japan has claimed what it calls the Senkaku islands since 1895, while China has claimed them for centuries under the name of the Diaoyu isles.
The latest dispute was sparked in July when Japanese rightists erected a lighthouse and planted flags on the uninhabited rocky outcrop.
